abstract.para: Hourly surface water temperature data were collected by Seattle Public Utilities (SPU) Watershed Management Division (WMD) staff in stream habitats within bull trout (Salvelinus confluentus) distribution of the Cedar River Municipal Watershed (CRW), WA, 2005 - current. Additional water temperature data from partner agencies (USGS, etc.) may be available on agency websites. Water temperature data were recorded in the water column and represented surface water temperature regimes across different habitats used by different life stages of bull trout. Data enabled research and monitoring of stream rearing habitats for bull trout to determine spatial thermal limitations on distribution and potential impacts of climate change and water supply management on the population. Beginning in 2019, as part of a joint funding agreement (JFA), USGS and SPU began recording air temperature at three USGS gages (12115000, 12115500, 12114500). This information could help SPU determine spatial and temporal sensitivity of surface water temperature to air temperature.

Hourly surface water temperature data were collected by SPU in lake and reservoir habitats of the CRW, WA, 2007 - current. Additional water temperature data from partner agencies (USGS, etc.) may be available on agency websites. During 2007 – 2011, water temperature data were recorded at different depths from surface to hypolimnion across seven different stations in Chester Morse Lake (CML) and Masonry Pool. Data were used to determine vertical and horizontal thermal limitations and potential impacts of climate change on bull trout in the reservoirs. In 2019, as part of the Water Temperature Monitoring Program (WTMP), SPU deployed two new temperature buoys, one in a deep area of CML and one in a deep area of Masonry Pool. Data from these loggers can be accessed from a proprietary dashboard and is also transmitted through SPU's SCADA system.
BULL TROUT REDD EGG POCKETS (Type = Egg pocket)

Hourly bull trout redd egg pocket water temperature data in stream habitat were collected by SPU beginning in December of 2023. This effort was initiated as part of a long-term fry emergence timing data collection program. The goal of this effort is to provide a representative sample of egg pocket conditions, and, along with fry counts collected from emergence traps, embryo development rate and fry emergence timing across representative habitats in stream habitats affected by reservoir inundation versus those unaffected. This information will be used to help SPU account for potential impacts to redd viability caused by reservoir management.

The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

geographicCoverage.geographicDescription: Chester Morse Lake basin, Cedar River Municipal Watershed, North Bend, WA

contact.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

description.para: BULL TROUT REDD EGG POCKETS
Cedar River (2023 - current)
Identification of candidate redds for fry emergence trapping:

The main concern over operational impacts to bull trout is impacts to embryos incubating in redds located in areas subjected to reservoir inundation. However, sampling of embryos in these areas is extremely difficult and probability of complete data and trap loss is elevated (SPU 2019). Instead of initiating the fry trapping program in an area where loss of data and traps is possible, SPU has identified an area where bull trout spawn in reliable abundance each year, where weekly access to the area throughout fall, winter, and spring is feasible, and where flow events will not affect traps and data collection (Eagle Ridge Side Channel). During the 2023 spawning period, a total of two (2) redds were "capped" using custom fry emergence traps in Eagle Ridge Creek Side Channel. Information from trapping efforts will enable assessment of accumulated thermal unit (ATU) requirements for emergence of bull trout fry. Fry emergence trap dimensions (2.5’ x 3.5’) will limit the size of redd that can be effectively trapped.
Procedure for sampling water quality variables and fry emergence timing distributions :
Water quality variables:

To sample environmental conditions in egg pockets and to calculate ATU requirements across fry emergence distributions, the egg pocket area of each trapped redd must be sampled for water temperature and dissolved oxygen (DO). As redds are observed in Eagle Ridge Side Channel, those of appropriate size (length and width) will be marked with GPS coordinates. The SPU lead biologist will select a single redd from the candidates for each period (early and late), and a water quality sensor will be deployed near the egg pocket in the redd. The lead fish biologist will carefully remove substrate from the probable egg pocket area (center of the tailspill) until the top and edges of the egg pocket are located (egg pocket: space in gravel containing 5 or more eggs separated by no more than a few egg diameters, DeVries 1997; Crisp and Carling 1989; Weeber et al. 2010). Once the perimeter of the egg pocket is determined, substrate will be replaced over the egg pocket and a 2” diameter perforated steel housing unit that contains a DO/temperature sensor (Onset HOBO U26) will be inserted into the streambed outside the perimeter of the egg pocket (Figure 3). The steel housing will then be zip tied to rebar that is driven deeper into the streambed as an anchor. The sensor in the housing will continuously record temperature and DO at egg pocket depth in the redd and will be accessible for weekly downloads and maintenance through a removable lid in the housing. After housing deployment, the redd will be fenced off using mesh fencing and fence posts around the perimeter to prohibit subsequent spawning or superimposition over the redd. A temperature sensor will also be deployed on the rebar in the water column at each redd to determine spatial differences in groundwater influences at egg pocket depths across different habitats used by spawners.

Based on previous use of the methodology and referencing the designs of other fry traps in the scientific literature, two fry traps were designed by SPU Watershed Management Division’s senior fish biologist and constructed by SPU’s equipment and facilities shop and a seamstress contractor (Figure 4). Monitoring of real-time surface water temperature at a stream gage (USGS 12115000) and periodic downloads of the egg pocket DO and temperature sensor prior to trap deployment will provide approximation of embryo development stage, which is the information needed to determine when the trap will be deployed, i.e., when the redd will be capped and emergent fry will be sampled. Based on information SPU has on file from previous fry emergence trapping efforts, the earliest date the trap would be deployed is after 500 ATU and no later than 600 ATU (Bowerman et al. 2014).
Fry emergence timing distribution:

Fry will be sampled at each trap by collecting them from a cod end, fine mesh-lined, 6” diameter by 12” long PVC housing and by dip netting inside the trap (cap) itself through a small zipper opening in the trap mesh. First, the trap’s outlet 4” hose will be clamped using a hose clamp to prohibit additional fry from moving into the hose, and the cod end will be carefully lifted from the streambed. The cod end will be submerged in a bucket of fresh stream water and the cap removed to allow fry to swim out of the cod end and into the bucket. Fry will then be counted and released to stream margins immediately using an aquarium net. Next, the zipper in the trap mesh will be opened so the biologist can fit a larger aquarium net and ensure any emerged fry that did not move into the cod end but located in the trap are captured. Once captured, these fry will be placed in a bucket of fresh stream water, counted, and returned to the stream margin. Finally, the hose clamp will be removed, the cod end will be lifted from the streambed again, and fry will be removed as in step one to ensure all fry in the trap, hose, and cod end have been counted for the sample date.
STREAMS
Various sites (2005 - 2009):

Hourly surface water temperature data collected in selected stream habitats. Onset HOBO Water Temperature Pro v2 Data Logger, U22-001 used at all stations. Loggers were placed in perforated PVC and zip tied to a rebar anchor. PVC housings were tethered using rope attached to nearby stationary objects.
Various sites (2019 - current):

Hourly surface water temperature data collected in selected stream habitats. Onset HOBO Water Temperature Pro v2 Data Logger, U22-001 used at all stations. Either Onset HOBO Water Temperature Pro v2 Data Logger U22-001 or HOBO TidbiT v2 Water Temperature Data Logger UTBI-001 were used at stations. Stainless 3/16" cable was inserted through the eyelet of U22 loggers and secured using a stainless cable clamp. The other end of the cable was secured to nearby stationary objects. A rebar was driven into the streambed and the cabled logger was secured to the rebar using heavy duty plastic zip ties. For TidbiTs, a heavy duty stainless keyring was inserted through the eyelet of the logger, stainless 3/16" cable was secured to the keyring using stainless crosby clamps, and the keyring was secured to the rebar using heavy duty plastic zip ties. A station-referenced data management spreadsheet was created to document logger serial numbers, site names, coordinates, habitat types, deployments, and maintenance, download and general station management activities.
LAKES AND RESERVOIRS
CML and Masonry Pool (2007 - 2011)

Hourly water temperature data were collected at seven stations in reservoirs (CML and Masonry Pool). Each station consisted of a 3/16" stainless mooring cable connected to a float on one end and an anchor on the other, with Onset HOBO U22-001's attached at different depths to determine periods of thermal mixing and stratification. Substantial diagonal tethering between the anchor and float, and movement of stations occurred as a result of fluctuations in reservoir level and lack of heavier chain attached to the mooring cable that would have enabled stationary, vertical alignment throughout reservoir fluctuations, rendering questionable accuracy of some data.
CML and Masonry Pool (2019 - 2024)

Hourly water temperature data were collected at two stations in reservoirs (one in CML and one in Masonry Pool). The CML station consisted of a 3/16" stainless mooring cable connected to three 20" floats on one end, 30' of 3/4" galvanized chain on the other, and the other end of the chain was attached to an anchor. Five Onset HOBO U22-001's were attached to the cable at different depths to determine periods of thermal mixing and stratification. The Masonry Pool station consisted of 75' of 3/8" galvanized mooring chain connected to three 20" floats. By using chain, diagonal tethering between the anchor and float and movement of stations were eliminated rendering reliably accurate depth data. However, manual downloading required lifting of all components, which was hazardous and nearly infeasible.
CML and Masonry Pool (2023 - current)

Two NexSens CB-250 data buoys were purchased using WMD IT, HCP WTMP, and Instream Flow Committee funds. Buoys were deployed in Masonry Pool on July 6, 2023 and in CML on XXXX XX, 2024. These iridium cellular data buoys eliminated unnecessary exposure to risks associated with management of the previous buoy systems. Temperature loggers were installed on a mooring line off a central solar/battery powered data collection/transmission buoy. Cables on either side of this buoy were attached to floats, which were attached to cable and chain that were attached to anchors. Due to much greater fluctuations in Masonry Pool, only chain was used for the anchors. Real-time temperature data is accessible via a proprietary web-based dashboard (WQData Live) or through SPU's SCADA system, and is used to determine volume of thermally suitable lake habitat the potential for bull trout presence in Masonry Pool after summer pool-split. Pool-split creates a potential passage barrier. If thermally sensitive bull trout are present in Masonry Pool and trapped after pool-split, subsequent drawdown of the Pool could lead to large-scale impacts on the bull trout population (i.e., fish kill) due to lack of thermal stratification, and therefore summer thermal refuge in Masonry Pool. If temperatures indicate bull presence is likely, additional monitoring efforts are triggered and resources can be mobilized to help SPU avoid potential population-level impacts, i.e., to avoid a fish kill.
Walsh Lake (2022-current)

Hourly water temperature data are collected at a data buoy station in the deepest area of Walsh Lake. Temperature loggers were installed on a mooring line attached to a buoy. Cables on either side of this buoy were attached to floats, which were attached to cable and chain that were attached to anchors. This buoy was deployed to learn about timing and magnitude of thermal stratification. This information inform WMD NRS staff of conditions for the native fish community in Walsh Lake, and also the potential for reintroductions, such as kokanee salmon (Oncorhynchus nerka). Onset HOBO U22-001 units were attached to the mooring chain at different depths to determine periods of thermal mixing and stratification. An Onset U26 temperature and dissolved oxygen (DO) logger was also installed at the 25-foot isotherm to determine oxygen conditions in the hypolimnion during thermal stratification.
Rattlesnake Lake (2024-current)

Large-scale fish kills occurred in man-made Rattlesnake Lake during late fall and winter months of 2022 - 2024. Seasonal water surface elevations (WSE) were much lower during these years than had been previously recorded. The fish kills suggest potential seasonal reduction in carrying capacity caused by the low WSE, which likely correlates with reduced DO and food sources for the fish in the Lake. Instantaneous water temperature and DO will be recorded at depth intervals from a personal watercraft using a YSI handheld device beginning in spring of 2024. This information is needed to help SPU understand temperature and DO dynamics in the lake. Water surface elevation of Rattlesnake Lake is dependent on seepage rate through the Cedar Moraine, which is dependent on water surface elevation of Masonry Pool. Thus, reservoir management may be indirectly causing the fish kills. The SPU WMD fish biologist is working directly with the Washington Department of Fish and Wildlife's Lake fishery Program manager to provide information for best fishery management practices to avoid overplanting of game fish and avoid future fish kills.

personnel.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: The objective for water temperature monitoring above Masonry Dam is to determine if water temperatures in habitats of the Cedar and Rex rivers and Chester Morse Lake (CML) remain hospitable to bull trout as the climate and reservoir management change. Thermal characteristics of riverine habitats used by bull trout among life stages in the CRW above Masonry Dam remain poorly understood. Thermal regimes vary among different stream habitats, and different life stages of bull trout have different thermal requirements and tolerances. Persistence of the species is, in part, linked to the protection and maintenance of a broad diversity of thermally mediated habitats.

dataTable.entityDescription: Hourly surface water temperature recorded across several stream systems and habitats within systems

Dissolved oxygen concentration in milligrams per liter. These data were collected in two locations, 1) the hyporheic zone near the egg pocket of bull trout redds in the upper Cedar River and 2) in the hypolimnion of Walsh Lake.
